result.markdown:
--- warning: false --- # Lab: Seaborn Seaborn is another plotting library. Some consider it the [`ggplot`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/) of Python with excellent default setting which make your data life easier. There is rather good [documentation online](https://seaborn.pydata.org/) and it comes with Anaconda Python. ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import pandas as pd import seaborn as sns ``` ::: We can load and create the same plots as before. ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} office_df = pd.read_csv('data/raw/office_ratings.csv', encoding='UTF-8') office_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
0 1 1 Pilot 7.6 3706 2005-03-24
1 1 2 Diversity Day 8.3 3566 2005-03-29
2 1 3 Health Care 7.9 2983 2005-04-05
3 1 4 The Alliance 8.1 2886 2005-04-12
4 1 5 Basketball 8.4 3179 2005-04-19
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.relplot(x='total_votes', y='imdb_rating', data=office_df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_2_4_files/figure-html/cell-4-output-1.png){width=470 height=468} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} office_df['air_date'] = pd.to_datetime(office_df['air_date'], errors='ignore') g = sns.relplot(x="air_date", y="imdb_rating", kind="scatter", data=office_df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_2_4_files/figure-html/cell-5-output-1.png){width=469 height=468} ::: ::: ## Functions We can define our own functions. A function helps us with code we are going to run multiple times. For instance, the below function scales values between 0 and 1. Here is a modified function from [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26414913/normalize-columns-of-pandas-data-frame). ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} office_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
0 1 1 Pilot 7.6 3706 2005-03-24
1 1 2 Diversity Day 8.3 3566 2005-03-29
2 1 3 Health Care 7.9 2983 2005-04-05
3 1 4 The Alliance 8.1 2886 2005-04-12
4 1 5 Basketball 8.4 3179 2005-04-19
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} def normalize(df, feature_name): result = df.copy() max_value = df[feature_name].max() min_value = df[feature_name].min() result[feature_name] = (df[feature_name] - min_value) / (max_value - min_value) return result ``` ::: Passing the dataframe and name of the column will return a dataframe with that column scaled between 0 and 1. ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} normalize(office_df, 'imdb_rating') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
0 1 1 Pilot 0.300000 3706 2005-03-24
1 1 2 Diversity Day 0.533333 3566 2005-03-29
2 1 3 Health Care 0.400000 2983 2005-04-05
3 1 4 The Alliance 0.466667 2886 2005-04-12
4 1 5 Basketball 0.566667 3179 2005-04-19
... ... ... ... ... ... ...
183 9 19 Stairmageddon 0.433333 1484 2013-04-11
184 9 20 Paper Airplane 0.433333 1482 2013-04-25
185 9 21 Livin' the Dream 0.733333 2041 2013-05-02
186 9 22 A.A.R.M. 0.866667 2860 2013-05-09
187 9 23 Finale 1.000000 7934 2013-05-16

188 rows × 6 columns

``` ::: ::: Replacing the origonal dataframe. We can normalize both out votes and rating. ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} office_df = normalize(office_df, 'imdb_rating') ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} office_df = normalize(office_df, 'total_votes') ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} office_df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
0 1 1 Pilot 0.300000 0.353616 2005-03-24
1 1 2 Diversity Day 0.533333 0.332212 2005-03-29
2 1 3 Health Care 0.400000 0.243082 2005-04-05
3 1 4 The Alliance 0.466667 0.228253 2005-04-12
4 1 5 Basketball 0.566667 0.273047 2005-04-19
... ... ... ... ... ... ...
183 9 19 Stairmageddon 0.433333 0.013912 2013-04-11
184 9 20 Paper Airplane 0.433333 0.013606 2013-04-25
185 9 21 Livin' the Dream 0.733333 0.099067 2013-05-02
186 9 22 A.A.R.M. 0.866667 0.224278 2013-05-09
187 9 23 Finale 1.000000 1.000000 2013-05-16

188 rows × 6 columns

``` ::: ::: Seaborn prefers a long format table. Details of melt can be found [here](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.melt.html). ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} office_df_long=pd.melt(office_df, id_vars=['season', 'episode', 'title', 'air_date'], value_vars=['imdb_rating', 'total_votes']) office_df_long ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ```{=html}
season episode title air_date variable value
0 1 1 Pilot 2005-03-24 imdb_rating 0.300000
1 1 2 Diversity Day 2005-03-29 imdb_rating 0.533333
2 1 3 Health Care 2005-04-05 imdb_rating 0.400000
3 1 4 The Alliance 2005-04-12 imdb_rating 0.466667
4 1 5 Basketball 2005-04-19 imdb_rating 0.566667
... ... ... ... ... ... ...
371 9 19 Stairmageddon 2013-04-11 total_votes 0.013912
372 9 20 Paper Airplane 2013-04-25 total_votes 0.013606
373 9 21 Livin' the Dream 2013-05-02 total_votes 0.099067
374 9 22 A.A.R.M. 2013-05-09 total_votes 0.224278
375 9 23 Finale 2013-05-16 total_votes 1.000000

376 rows × 6 columns

``` ::: ::: Which we can plot in seaborn like so. ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.relplot(x='air_date', y='value', size='variable', data=office_df_long) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_2_4_files/figure-html/cell-13-output-1.png){width=588 height=468} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} ?sns.relplot ``` :::
